ce:caption.ce:simple-para: a) FTIR spectra of Ni-Fe MOGs in different ratios (i∼vii: H3TATAB, Ni-MOG, Ni0.8Fe0.2, Ni0.6Fe0.4, Ni0.4Fe0.6, Ni0.2Fe0.8, Fe-MOG), b) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and c) pore size distributionsof Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG.

SEM micrographs of a) Ni-MOG, b) Fe-MOG, c) Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG samples. TEM micrographs of d,e,f) Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG samples (inset shows SAED pattern), g) mapping results of the elemental C (red), O (tiffany), N (green), Ni (yellow), and Fe (fuchsia) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.).

High-resolution XPS spectra of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG: a) C1 s, b) N1 s, c) O1 s. e) Ni 2p spectra comparison of Ni-Fe MOGs in different ratios (i∼v: Ni-MOG, Ni0.8Fe0.2, Ni0.6Fe0.4, Ni0.4Fe0.6, Ni0.2Fe0.8-MOG), f) Fe 2p spectra comparison of Ni-Fe MOGs in different ratios (i∼v: Fe-MOG, Ni0.8Fe0.2, Ni0.6Fe0.4, Ni0.4Fe0.6, Ni0.2Fe0.8-MOG).

OER linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) of a) Ni-Fe MOGs in different ratios and RuO2 in 1 M KOH solution (with IR correction). b) the corresponding Tafel plots for all samples, c) the overpotential of Ni-Fe MOGs in different ratios (at 10, 50 and 100 mA cm−2), d) capacitive current densities plotted against scan rates (CV curves at various scan rates (2∼10 mV s-1) inset), e) Nyquist plots obtained by EIS, f) the chronoamperometry test of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (at 10 and 100 mA cm−2) and RuO2 (10 mA cm−2), g) OER LSVs of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (NF) and Ni Foam, h) OER LSVs of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (0.1 M KOH), i) comparison for OER activity of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG with some well-studied electrocatalyst in 1 M and 0.1 M KOH (gradient color for 1 M KOH and solid color for 0.1 M KOH).

HER linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) of a) Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (NF), b) NiFe-MOGs in different ratios and Pt/C in 1 M KOH solution with GCE (with IR correction), c) the corresponding Tafel plots for all samples, d) the chronoamperometry test of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (at 10 mA cm−2), e) overall water splitting electrocatalysis by the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG||Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG, Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG||Pt/C and the benchmark RuO2 ||Pt/C, f) the chronoamperometry test of overall water splitting electrocatalysis (Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG||Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG).
Simulated gelation process: the assembly of gel factor and mismatched growth of gel factor.

head.ce:title: Facile coordination driven synthesis of metal-organic gels toward efficiently electrocatalytic overall water splitting

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A series of MOGs were prepared for high-efficiency electrocatalytic overall water splitting. The Ni0.6Fe0.4 MOG exhibited the highest electrocatalytic activity.

ce:section.ce:para: Plenty of fossil fuels consumption, has causing the deterioration of environment and depletion of conventional resources in recent years [1,2]. Consequently, researchers are continually searching for renewable energy sources to secure a sustainable future [3–5]. Hydrogen, which has the advantages of high energy density and carbon-free-emissions property, is a viable alternative energy carrier for traditional fossil fuels. But now, most hydrogen is derived from fossil fuels. Hydrogen production by electrolysis of water splitting, including oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), accounts for only 5% [6]. There are two main factors restricting its application, the requirement of high purity of water and the relatively low activity and stability of the catalysts. Especially for the vital half-reaction of multistep OER, which requires four electrons to complete, is the key to electrolysis of water [7]. Therefore, the development of efficient OER catalysts to reduce overpotential and improvement of kinetics are urgently needed.

Over the past few decades, enormous effort has been devoted and tens of thousands catalysts for OER have been reported. Up to now, noble metal-based materials such as RuO2 and IrO2 are still considered to be the more excellent catalysts for OER [8], which are already used in proton exchange membrane electrolysis water equipment. However, the scarcity and low durability limited their large-scale commercial electrolysis of water [9,10]. Except for precious metals, the earth-abundant transition metals show significant advantages towards OER. In particular, the metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on Fe, Co, and Ni, have experienced fast growth and become a promising type of electrocatalyst [11,12]. However, the poor intrinsic conductivity of organic ligands gives rise to the lack of conductivity for most MOFs and further suppress the catalytic activity [13]. To improve the catalytic performance, researchers have to adopt some certain measures such as doping other metals, controlling dimension, compositing with conductive substrate, regulating defects, and others to change and control the morphology and structure of MOFs [14–20].

With the same root homology as MOFs, metal-organic gels (MOGs) are also a kind of coordination-driven supramolecular polymer. It’s unique in that the metal ions and ligands first generate the gel factors by self-assembly [21,22]. Then the fibrous, flake, or granular gel factors further form a staggered three-dimensional network structure through intermolecular forces such as intermolecular hydrogen bonds, π-π stacking, and van der Waals forces [23,24]. Unlike the harsh synthesis conditions that usually proceed in the organic media of most MOFs, the MOGs form under much milder aqueous-phase condition (normal temperature and pressure and short reaction time) will be more attractive. As a three-dimensional cross-linked metal organic polymer, which has tunable hierarchically porous architecture, low density, diverse functional ligands, and well-defined metal centers [21], to some extent, may be able to break the shackles of current catalysts and have the vast stage in electrocatalysis [25].

Recently, through a one-pot synthesis of terpyridines and Co(ⅠⅠ) salts in methanol and chloroform mixture, a series of new metallogels were obtained that exhibited highly efficiency for OER [26], in which the well-developed 3D nanosheet network enhance the conductivity [27]. In addition, by a propylene oxide dispersion triggered gelation method, a current work reported a NiFe-gel achieving a high OER electrocatalytic activity [28]. More importantly, there is a synergistic effect between Ni and Fe in bimetallic materials correlated to its catalytic activity [29,30], accordingly, which also inspire us to make some new related attempts.

In this work, through an extremely simple one-step aqueous-phase synthesis method, we have reported a new class of coordination polymer catalysts that were obtained adopting freeze-drying the MOGs through simply mixing the precursor solutions. Herein, MOGs using nitrogen-containing tricarboxylic acid ligands and various metal salts were prepared under room temperature and normal pressure. Owing to the well-developed nanofiber network, unique nitrogenous ligands, and synergistic effects of NiFe, the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG exhibits the most remarkable OER catalytic activity (285 mV at 10 mA, 347 mV at 100 mA, 399 mV at 300 mA, and 445 mV at 500 mA) than samples with other ratios and benchmark RuO2. Notably,the small Tafel slopes and EIS are much superior to most reported non-precious catalysts. Simultaneously, it can also catalyze the HER, enabling the whole water splitting. The alkaline electrolyzer which is assembled by using the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG as both cathode and anode, achieves a low cell voltage of 1.61 V at j 10.

H3TATAB (4,4′,4″-s-triazine-1,3,5-triyltri-p-aminobenzoic acid) was prepared according to the method of previous reported literature [31]. NiCl2·6H2O (99 %), FeCl3·6H2O (99 %), CoCl2·6H2O (99 %), CuCl2·2H2O (99 %), ZnCl2 (99 %) and MnCl2·4H2O (99 %) were obtained from China National Pharmaceutical Group Corporation. CeCl3·7H2O (99 %), RuCl3 and RhCl3·3H2O (99 %) were purchased from Aladdin. RuO2 (99.9 %), commercial 20 % Pt/C, and triethylamine (99 %) were gained from Macklin. Nafion solution (5 wt%) was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. The electrodes we used in tests were purchased from Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Company. All reagents were analytical grade without purification.

The synthesis methods of all MOGs were derived from the previous literature [32]. Herein, we take the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG as an example. The 20 mM Ni2+ and Fe3+ precursor solutions were prepared by dissolving NiCl2·6H2O and FeCl3·6H2O into deionized water respectively. According to the same approach, we obtained the ligand solution of the same concentration with 20 μL triethylamine in each milliliter of solution, which plays a role of deprotonation hydrotropic agent and coagulant aid. Then by evenly mixing 200 μL Fe3+, 300 μL Ni2+, and 500 μL ligands solution in 5 ml tube, the mixture will gel on standing in 30 min. After that, three steps of freeze-drying, three times washing with deionized water, and drying were taken to obtain the target product denoted Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG.

To characterize the structure and chemical state of samples, X-ray diffraction patterns were performed by Rigaku X-ray diffractormeter. The surface morphology and structure were obtained using a JSM-7900 F Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and a JEOL JEM-ARM200CF Atomic Resolution S/TEM. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-Alpha, USA) was tested ESCALAB 250Xi instrument. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum data in the range of 4000−400 cm−1 were collected on Nicolet 460 spectrophotometer by KBr pellets. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area was calculated using the BET equation carried out on ASAP 2460 apparatus. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of samples were measured with a heating rate of 10 ℃ min−1 from 40 to 1000 ℃ by STA 449.

The homogeneous catalyst ink was obtained by dispersing 5 mg as-prepared catalyst and 40 μL 5 wt% Nafion into a mixed solvent containing 0.6 mL ethanol and 0.4 mL pure water and one-hour ultrasonication.

The electrochemical tests in experiment were carried out on a CHI 760E electrochemical work station (Instruments Inc., Shanghai) in 1 M KOH to measure the OER and HER performances of prepared catalysts, which uses a typical three-electrode configuration containing a polished glassy carbon (GC) electrode (working electrode), a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) (reference electrode) and a graphite rod (counter electrode). On the central mirror-like GC surface (3 mm in diameter), 5 μL catalyst ink was pipetted (0.35 mg·cm−2) and then dried at room temperature. In this study, all potentials were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) showing as the calibration Eq. (1):
(1) ERHE = ESCE+ 0.059*pH
the polarization curves shown in plots were corrected for ohmic losses as Eq. (2) :
(2) ECorrect = ERHE - IR(95 %)
where I is measured current and R is the resistence of the solution (∼9.3 Ω).

After 20 cyclic voltammetry cycles at 50 mV s−1 which were performed in the range of 1.2–1.8 V (-0.7 to 0 V for HER) vs. SCE to activate the catalysts, the LSV curves of OER was measured in an O2-saturated 1 M KOH (N2-saturated 1 M KOH for HER) at the scan rate of 5 mV s−1. The Tafel plots were obtained by reploting the polarization curves as η versus log current (j) at regions. At the same time, to characterize the resistance for catalysts, The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were carried out on Gamry Reference 600+ in the frequency range of 100 kHz ∼0.01 Hz at the current density of 10 mA cm-2. And through conducting CV at the scan rate of 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 mV in the non-Faradaic region ranging from 1.3 to 1.4 V, the double layer specific capacitance (C dl) was obtained to estimate the ECSA. For the overall water splitting, two electrodes through drop-casting ink droplets on the as-prepared nickel foams with the same load were assembled a two-electrode cell as both cathode and anode and the measurements were conducted in 1 M KOH.

Here are the formula used the Faraday’s law to calculated from the total charge passing through the system in unit time:
Faradic efficiency = (nF × m)/Q,
n = 4 for OER (2 for HER),
F = 96485.3 A s mol−1,
m = the moles number of O2 (H2),
Q = It.

As shown in Scheme 1 , the schematic of the synthesis process has performed that the environmentally friendly water-based gels were prepared by an ultra-simple method. Two steps of gelation may be divided. First, the self-assembled process was took placed in the mixed solution between the free metal ions and deprotonated TATAB ligands. Then, the gel factor extended into a nanofiber network through mismatched growth.

In terms of the MOGs based on different metals, only 0.5 hours to 3 hours were needed for the entire gelling process. Among all metals, Co and Zn possessed the fastest coagulation speed and the best coagulation effect. Notably, the above method exhibit superior universality. Herein, transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Mn) were all used to synthesis the MOGs, which have provided abundant and manifold metal source as active centers to contact the target molecule [33]. Fig. S1 has listed the photographs of MOGs. Among them, the powders of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG and Co-MOG after freeze-drying are shown in Fig. S2. In addition, the carboxyl groups in the tricarboxylic acid ligand (Scheme 1 above) exhibit variegated coordination modes and promote the formation of hydrogen bonds during the gel formation process. The abundant nitrogen atoms in the ligand are uniformly doped in-situ in the material as heteroatoms, which enhance the catalytic activity [34].

To investigate the formation mechanism of gel, we took FT-IR to explore. The FT-IR has revealed the interaction between ligand and metal ions (Fig. 1 a). The peak at 1694 cm−1, which is always depicted the stretching vibration of CO of H3TATAB, moved to 1607 cm−1 after coordinating with metal ions (blue part). And as expected, the stretching vibration of CO and the out-of-plane bending vibration of OH almost passed off [35]. At the same time, since the -NH- group promotes the formation of hydrogen bonds during the gel formation, the peak located 3417 cm−1 disappeared (violet part) [36]. The structure of MOGs were characterized by XRD. As displayed in Fig. S3, only a wide-angle diffraction peak at 2θ = 24.5 ° in the XRD spectrum was observed, which means there is no long range ordered crystal structure, that is, the gel has an amorphous structure. The corresponding interplanar spacing to this peak is 3.64 Å (calculated according to Bragg's Law), proving the existence of π-π conjugation in the process of gel formation [37]. The percentage of TATAB3- in the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG sample was characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and found to be ≈72 wt% (Fig. S4). As obtained from N2 adsorption/desorption analysis (Fig. 1b), the BET surface area of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG was up to be 163.86 m2/g and the pore volume was 0.38 cm3/g (under P/P0 = 0.95). The rapid adsorption of N2 (P/P0<0.01), the hysteresis between the adsorption and desorption isotherm and the sharp increase of adsorbed N2 (P/P0>0.90), have together proved simultaneous existence of hierarchical pores (Fig. 1c).

The results of SEM were shown in Fig. 2 . A typical cross-linked nanofiber network structure of Ni-MOG, Fe-MOG, and Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG has been unfolded in Fig. 2a-c, respectively. The unique well-developed nanofiber network performed enhanced conductivity. Simultaneously, disordered multiscale pore structure could facilitate mass transport and benefit the sufficient contact of reactants and active sites of catalyst, which can also be confirmed by the BET surface area and the pore size distributions above.

And it is worth complementing the MOGs based on specific metals that would produce different morphologies. For instance, unlike the Ni-Fe MOG, the nanofibers that make up Fe-MOG show a disorganized root-like structure (Fig. 2b). And the Zn-MOG displayed a flaky structure macroscopically and a granular structure microscopically (Fig. S5f). It is worth noting that through a long-time placing in air, some crystals sometimes precipitate as the solvent volatilizing (Fig. S5g-S5i). The TEM images have also proved the 3D network structure of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (Fig. 2d, f). Furthermore, after a period of ultrasound, the image exhibits a net-like structure woven from nanofibers on a larger scale (Fig. 2e). This kind of Ni-foam-like structure has greatly enhanced the conductivity of the material. The corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) in Fig. 2d (inset), shows a hazy haloes pattern, implying that the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG has poor crystallinity. EDS (Energy dispersive spectroscopy) element mapping (C, N, O, Ni and Fe) result confirmed homogeneously element distribution (Fig. 2g).

The surface valence and bonding configurations were evaluated by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. 3 ). XPS analysis revealed thepresence of C1 s, N1 s, O1 s, Ni 2p, and Fe 2p in Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (Fig. S7). According to the XPS data (Fig. 3a), the C 1s spectrum could be fitted with four peaks at 284.6, 285.8, 288.2, and 290.6 eV which proved the presence of CC, CN/CN, CO, and OCO functional groups [38]. The N 1s exhibited four separated peaks at 398.6, 400.1, 401.1, and 406.1 eV, each of them attributing to the overlap of pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphitic-N, and oxidized N (Fig. 3b) [39]. Significantly, the pyrrolic N, together with the pyridinic N have accounted for 60.44 % and 31.42 %, respectively, much higher than the other three N species, which could be result from the intrinsic properties of unheated gel. A great quantity of pyrrolic N could optimize the adsorption of OOH* intermediates [40]. Besides, reported by previous literature, the pyridinic N were deemed as the active site of the four-electron process [41]. The O 1s XPS spectrum was deconvolved into two peaks centered at 531.1 and 533.1 eV, which were assigned the Fe/Ni-O and O-C=O (Fig. 3c) [42]. In our case, we have compared six samples with different NiFe ratios (Fig. 3d,e). As for the Ni 2p signal, doublet peaks of Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 were emerged at 856.0 and 873.6 eV, and the satellite peaks were positioned at 861.4 and 879.9 eV, suggesting the existence of Ni2+ [43]. In the high-resolution of Fe 2p spectrum of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG, the two main peaks located 711.4 and 724.8 eV were attributed to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, and the fitted peaks around 711.3 and 724.8 eV, together with the two satellite peaks at 716.4 and 731.0 eV that could be indexed into the oxidation state of Fe3+ [44].

The result of comparison diagram (Fig. 3d) demonstrated the effect that the Ni 2p spectral peaks of NiFe bimetallic MOGs shifted to lower binding energy with the incorporation of nickel compared with the Ni-MOG, unveiling the decline of electron density of Ni, which can also be observed in the Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 3e). This behavior of peak position shifting could be explained as that strong electronic interaction from Ni and Fe may modulate electronic environment and further enhance the catalytic performance [45].

To ascertain electrocatalytic activities of different MOGs, we first investigated their OER performance (Fig. S9-S11). The Fig. S9 has displayed the OER performance of all bimetallic MOGs with Fe (FexM21-x-MOGs), Fig. S10 for CoxM21-x-MOGs, Fig. S11 for CuxM21-x-MOGs and ZnxMn1-x. Through conducting a large amount of OER tests, we have summarized 21 samples with pretty well OER properties in Table S1. And an interesting phenomenon has emerged that the incorporation of iron into any MOGs based on single metal would improve the catalytic performance of the material to a large extent. It can be seen that the NiFe-MOGs showed the most negative potential and the largest stable current density (Fig. 4 a), especially the one with 3:2 Ni/Fe ratio, which can be clearly distinguished from the overpotential diagram (Fig. 4c). We have measured the cyclic voltammetry curve for Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG at the range of 0∼0.6 V (GCE, 0.07065 cm−2). The CV curve displayed a pair of obvious redox peaks, which can be explained as the redox peak of conversion between Ni2+ and Ni3+ (Fig. S17). The Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG requires a small overpotential as low as 285 mV, 347 mV, 399 mV, and 445 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm-2, 100 mA cm-2, 300 mA cm-2, and 500 mA cm-2 (Fig. S12) respectively, which has the highest activity of all NiFe-MOGs with different ratios and commercial RuO2 (342 mV at 10 mA cm-2), being superior to most of reported virgin polymer catalysts (with GC electrode), especially at high current density (Fig. 4i, Table S2).

What is more, the kinetics for OER of prepared catalysts are showed as the Tafel slope in Fig. 4b, the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG exhibits a much smaller value of about 33 mV dec−1 than RuO2 (68 mV dec−1), which could be an evidence of excellent charge transfer ability and advanced OER catalytic activity. The charge transfer resistance (Rct), which is always used to value the interfacial properties, was obtained through measuring the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). As is shown in Fig. 4e, Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG exhibits a low Rct value of 2 Ω, while the values of other counterparts are higher than it, indicating that the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG owns the fastest charge transfer capability. Meanwhile, the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG has a higher double-layer capacitance (indicating the intrinsic electrochemical active surface area) of 19.63 mF cm-2 (Fig. 4d), which can be explained by the fact that the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG owns a large specific surface area among all NiFe MOGs (163.86 m2/g). And the CV curves at various scan rates (2∼10 mV) for NiFe MOGs in other ratios and RuO2 were shown in Fig. S14. In contrast, the low Tafel slope, together with the ultra-low Rct value, has given eloquent proof of that the prepared Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG is a superior OER catalyst.

And on the basis of extensive exploration in the previous transition metal gels, we have also attempted to synthesize a series of bimetallic gels using Ce and the above metals and explored their OER performance (Fig. S13).

Of note, we have also measured the OER performance of the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG by loading it on the Ni foam in 1 M KOH (Fig. 4g). At this time, an ultra-low overpotential of 173 mV (10 mA) was achieved. And we have tried to enlarge voltage range when measuring the OER LSV and the glassy carbon electrode loaded with our catalyst can achieve a high current density of 600 mA cm−2 at 1.68 V (Fig. S12). To our great surprise, when we replaced the solution with 0.1 M KOH, an excellent catalytic property was observed (358 mV at 10 mA cm−2), while 481 mV for RuO2 (Fig. 4h), which is better than many previously reported non-noble-metals based polymer-supported catalysts (Fig. 4i, Table S3). Its Tafel slope is only 54 mV dec-1, much smaller than RuO2 (Fig. S16). SEM was carried out to characterize the structure and morphology after a long-term OER stability test (60,000 s). As confirmed by Fig. S19, despite that long-term cycle led to the gradual disappearance of the nano-network structure of the material, there was also a quantity of nanofiber structure preserved. Besides, we have performed the ICP and HRTEM for the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG samples (after 60,000 s and 120,000 s) to characterized the change of element ratio (Table S5) and transformation of morphology and structure (Fig. S20). The proportion of Ni and Fe remained basically unchanged after OER and HER stability test. It was observed that through long-term it test for 60,000 s, the micro-morphology displayed a coexistence of initial polymer network structure and oxide grid structure (Fig. S20a,b). And when the test running to 120,000 s, we could hardly found the polymer structure, which could completely convert to metal oxide (Fig. S20c,d,e,f). Even so, the OER activity maintained relatively stable during about 35 h stability test. Thus it could be see that there are slight impact on OER because of the transformation of the active sites. Through analyzing the results of HRTEM, clear and well-defined interplanar spacing such as the typical 0.21 nm, 0.24 nm (assigning to the (200) and (111) facet of NiO or (002) of NiOOH) and 0.27 nm and 0.365 nm (ascribing to the (104) (012) crystal plane of Fe2O3) [47,48]. In conclusion, during the process of OER, coordination metals could transmute into corresponding metal oxides (Fe2O3 and NiO or NiOOH).

About XPS (Fig. S21), in the Ni 2p spectrum, the peaks responding to the Ni2+ have shifted 1.3 eV to lower binding energies when comparing to the pristine Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG, indicating the increase of electron density. We speculated that it is due to that the Ni-O of NiO has took the place of Ni-O (coordination bond) in Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG, which may be ascribed to enhance of nuclear electrostatic shielding because of the replacement by bare O atom. And the peaks of Ni3+ appeared at 855.8 eV and 873.8 eV, which may be attributed to the formation of NiOOH. The similar negative shift of 1.35 eV has also occurred in Fe 2p spectrum, there may be Fe2O3 synthesized during the OER process. At the same time, these structural reorganization were also proved by the blue shift (1.0 eV) of the dominate peaks of O 1s. The two deconvolved peaks were attribute to M–O (Fe2O3/NiO) (531.6 eV) and OCO/OH (533.6 eV). In term of HER, the result of XPS showed no obvious change for Ni, Fe and O.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution and water splitting
ce:section.ce:para: Inspired by the excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability, as shown in Fig. 5e, the overall water-splitting electrolyzer was fabricated in which the bifunctional catalyst was served as both anode and cathode. With the RuO2||Pt/C as the benchmark (1.56 V), Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG||Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG needed a rather low voltage (1.61 V) to achieve j10 and 1.48 V for Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG||Pt/C. It can be seen that our Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG is a superior catalyst when comparing some advanced water splitting catalysts, especially in the field of polymer catalyst rarely reported (Fig. S22). Moreover, the NF||NF performance was also demonstrated in Fig. 5e, what we can see was that the electrolyzer assembled by Ni foam exhibited a poor activity (1.80 V) by contrast with the main sample, revealing a fact that the substrate does not provide much help to the electrocatalytic performance. Fig. 5f presented the super electrocatalytic durability (Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG||Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG) by recording the current-time curve. In the chronoamperometry test as long as 72000s, there are no significant decay in the first 60,000 s and only a slight decay (10 %) occurred finally. In terms of the turnover frequencies (TOF), it is assumed that all of Ni and Fe atoms are active sites of OER and HER process. The TOF were calculated on the basis of ICP data. The TOF value of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG was determined to 1.38 s−1 at the overpotential of 300 mV (1.44 s-1 for HER at 400 mV), which was higher than some reported excellent catalysts (Table S4). We have also estimated the Faradaic efficiency of OER and HER by comparing the measured actual gas production using the drainage method during the overall water splitting (H2 and O2) with the theoretical quantities based on the passed charge (Fig. S23 and S24). We could found that the practical measurement data matched the theoretical value well, through calculating, the Faradaic efficiency could reach nearly 100 %, indicating no side reactions during OER and HER occured. And there are no significant element content change of Ni and Fe (Table S5).

Based on the above diverse characterization results, we can conjecture some possible reasons towards to high performance of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG. Just as we know, the electrocatalytic processes (OER, HER) occur on the surface of catalysts and therefore the morphology of material would make a significant impact on catalytic performance. Herein, the distinctive NF-like 3D network structure woven from nanofibers, could provide abundant pores benefiting the infiltration of electrolyte and further facilitating reaction process (optimize the mass transfer process) [49]. In addition, as covered, the excellent conductivity may be achieved by designing and synthesizing the low-dimensional catalyst recently. Thereby, the well-developed nanofiber network displayed by the MOGs, could explicate the high conductivity (optimize the charge transfer process) [27]. The third reason we speculate is that nickel and iron are considered owning excellent inherent electrochemical activity [50]. By means of adjusting the ratio of the two elements, not only the electronic structure has been optimized, but the conductivity would be enhanced accordingly [51]. The unique and superior structure, together with the synergy of Ni and Fe, working to heighten the conductivity. According to the previous literatures [52–54], here we speculated the unsaturated coordination metal sites are the active sites. And the concrete speculated mechanism for OER and HER were showed in Fig. S25. From the result of ICP, the ratio of Ni and Fe are similar to the feed ratio of Ni and Fe. In addition, the molar quantity of H3TATAB was equal to (or less due to the washing) the total quantity of Ni and Fe, from this, the coordination number provided by the ligands is much less than that required for metal saturation coordination. We can be speculated that the Ni and Fe atoms could not achieved saturated-coordination. To confirm the rationality of this point. We have synthesized a similar hexacarboxylic acid ligand (using the 5-aminoisophthalic acid as precusor) (Fig. S26a) and took the same method to synthesize the Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG by using H6TDPAT ligand (Fig. S26b), which own double number of carboxylic acid groups and could binding more metal sites to reduce the number of unsaturated coordination metal ions theoretically. As predicted, the deduction of unsaturated coordination metal ions bring about that the OER activity of Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (H6TDPAT) was worse than Ni0.6Fe0.4-MOG (H3TATAB) (Fig. S26c).
The authors report no declarations of interest.

Xinghao Zhang: Conceptualization, Methodology, Writing - original draft. Huihui Zhao: Data curation, Software. Chen Li: Formal analysis, Visualization, Investigation. Shaoxiang Li: Validation. Kang Liu: Software, Supervision, Funding acquisition. Lei Wang: Resources.
